message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Continuous symmetry breaking in a two-dimensional Rydberg array
Paper Abstract: Spontaneous symmetry breaking underlies much of our classification of phases of matter and their associated transitions<sup>1-3</sup>. The nature of the underlying symmetry being broken determines many of the qualitative properties of the phase; this is illustrated by the case of discrete versus continuous symmetry breaking. Indeed, in contrast to the discrete case, the breaking of a continuous symmetry leads to the emergence of gapless Goldstone modes controlling, for instance, the thermodynamic stability of the ordered phase<sup>4,5</sup>. Here, we realize a two-dimensional dipolar XY model that shows a continuous spin-rotational symmetry using a programmable Rydberg quantum simulator. We demonstrate the adiabatic preparation of correlated low-temperature states of both the XY ferromagnet and the XY antiferromagnet. In the ferromagnetic case, we characterize the presence of a long-range XY order, a feature prohibited in the absence of long-range dipolar interaction. Our exploration of the many-body physics of XY interactions complements recent works using the Rydberg-blockade mechanism to realize Ising-type interactions showing discrete spin rotation symmetry<sup>6-9</sup>.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Dipole interaction"

Links: [{"title":"Magnetic dipole–dipole interaction","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetic_dipole–dipole_interaction"},{"title":"Intermolecular force - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intermolecular_force"},{"title":"File:Three State Model Electric Dipole interaction.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Three_State_Model_Electric_Dipole_interaction.svg"},{"title":"Dipole - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dipole"},{"title":"Electric dipole moment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_dipole_moment"},{"title":"Ewald summation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ewald_summation"},{"title":"London dispersion force - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_dispersion_force"},{"title":"Dipole (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dipole_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Non-covalent interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-covalent_interaction"},{"title":"Spin–orbit interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin–orbit_interaction"}]

Here are the key findings on dipole interactions:

## Types of Dipole Interactions

Magnetic dipole–dipole interaction, also called dipolar coupling, refers to the direct interaction between two magnetic dipoles.(no content)Roughly speaking, the magnetic field of a dipole goes as the inverse cube of the distance, and the force of its magnetic field on another dipole goes as the first derivative of this.(no content)Dipole-dipole interactions are electrostatic interactions between permanent dipoles in molecules. These interactions tend to align the molecules to increase attraction (reducing potential energy).

## Dipole-Induced Dipole Interactions

A dipole-induced dipole interaction (Debye force) is due to the approach of a molecule with a permanent dipole to another non-polar molecule with no permanent dipole. This approach causes the electrons of the non-polar molecule to be polarized toward or away from the dipole of the approaching molecule.

## Distance Dependence

The energy of a Keesom interaction depends on the inverse sixth power of the distance, unlike the interaction energy of two spatially fixed dipoles, which depends on the inverse third power of the distance.

## Related Intermolecular Forces

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about phases of matter:

## Overview

Four states of matter are observable in everyday life: solid, liquid, gas, and plasma.(no content)Different states are distinguished by the ways the component particles (atoms, molecules, ions and electrons) are arranged, and how they behave collectively.

## The Four Common States

**Solid:** In a solid, the particles are tightly packed and held in fixed positions, giving the material a definite shape and volume.

**Liquid:** In a liquid, the particles remain close together but can move past one another, allowing the substance to maintain a fixed volume while adapting to the shape of its container.

**Gas:** In a gas, the particles are far apart and move freely, allowing the substance to expand and fill both the shape and volume of its container.

**Plasma:** Plasma is similar to a gas, but it also contains charged particles (ions and free electrons) that move independently and respond to electric and magnetic fields.

## Other States and Phases

Beyond the four classical states, there are additional phases of matter. Some of these lie between the traditional categories; for example, liquid crystals exhibit properties of both solids and liquids.(no content)Some states occur only under extreme conditions, such as Bose–Einstein condensates and Fermionic condensates (in extreme cold), neutron-degenerate matter (in extreme density), and quark–gluon plasma (at extremely high energy).

## Phase Transitions

The state or phase of a given set of matter can change depending on pressure and temperature conditions, transitioning to other phases as these conditions change to favor their existence; for example, solid transitions to liquid with an increase in temperature.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Classical XY model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_XY_model"},{"title":"Kosterlitz–Thouless transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kosterlitz–Thouless_transition"},{"title":"Nicolet 1080 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicolet_1080"},{"title":"Ford Falcon (XY) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Falcon_(XY)"},{"title":"Cutter location - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cutter_location"},{"title":"Universality class - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_critical_exponents"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about the XY model:

## Overview

The classical XY model (sometimes also called classical rotor (rotator) model or O(2) model) is a lattice model of statistical mechanics.(no content)The XY model is a two-dimensional vector spin model that possesses U(1) or circular symmetry.

## Phase Transitions

The behavior of the XY model varies significantly depending on dimensionality:

- **One dimension**: In one dimension the XY model does not have a phase transition

- **Two dimensions**: In two dimensions it has the Berezinski-Kosterlitz-Thouless transition between the phases with exponentially and powerlaw decaying correlation functions.(no content)The Berezinskii–Kosterlitz–Thouless (BKT) transition is a phase transition of the two-dimensional (2-D) XY model in statistical physics. It is a transition from bound vortex-antivortex pairs at low temperatures to unpaired vortices and anti-vortices at some critical temperature.

- **Three and higher dimensions**: In three and higher dimensions the XY model has a ferromagnet-paramagnet phase transition.(no content)Many three-dimensional physical systems belong to the same universality class as the three dimensional XY model and share the same critical exponents, most notably easy-plane magnets and liquid Helium-4.

## Physical Representation

The spins can be represented as an arrow pointing in some direction, or as being represented as a point with some color. Here it is necessary to represent the spin with a spectrum of colors due to each of the possible continuous variables.

Links: [{"title":"Symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Chiral symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiral_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Spontaneous symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spontaneous_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"1964 PRL symmetry breaking papers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1964_PRL_symmetry_breaking_papers"},{"title":"Explicit symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explicit_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Symmetry-breaking constraints - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry-breaking_constraints"},{"title":"Symmetry breaking and cortical rotation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_Breaking_and_Cortical_Rotation"},{"title":"Symmetry breaking of escaping ants - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking_of_escaping_ants"},{"title":"Electroweak scale - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electroweak_scale"},{"title":"Higgs mechanism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Higgs_mechanism"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of symmetry breaking:

## Definition

In physics, symmetry breaking is a phenomenon where a disordered but symmetric state collapses into an ordered, but less symmetric state.

## Types of Symmetry Breaking

Symmetry breaking can be distinguished into two types, explicit and spontaneous. They are characterized by whether the equations of motion fail to be invariant, or the ground state fails to be invariant.

**Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking (SSB):** Spontaneous symmetry breaking occurs when this relation breaks down, while the underlying physical laws remain symmetrical.(no content)This is the idea that for a physical system, the lowest energy configuration (the vacuum state) is not the most symmetric configuration of the system.

**Explicit Symmetry Breaking:** In theoretical physics, explicit symmetry breaking is the breaking of a symmetry of a theory by terms in its defining equations of motion (most typically, to the Lagrangian or the Hamiltonian) that do not respect the symmetry.

## Significance in Physics

This phenomenon is fundamental to quantum field theory (QFT), and further, contemporary understandings of physics. Specifically, it plays a central role in the Glashow–Weinberg–Salam model which forms part of the Standard Model modelling the electroweak sector.

## Real-World Examples

Phases of matter, such as crystals, magnets, and conventional superconductors, as well as simple phase transitions can be described by spontaneous symmetry breaking. Additionally, symmetry breaking in biology is the process by which uniformity is broken, or the number of points to view invariance are reduced, to generate a more structured and improbable state.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of symmetry breaking:

## Definition

In physics, symmetry breaking is a phenomenon where a disordered but symmetric state collapses into an ordered, but less symmetric state.

## Types of Symmetry Breaking

Symmetry breaking can be distinguished into two types, explicit and spontaneous. They are characterized by whether the equations of motion fail to be invariant, or the ground state fails to be invariant.

**Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking (SSB):** Spontaneous symmetry breaking occurs when this relation breaks down, while the underlying physical laws remain symmetrical.(no content)This is the idea that for a physical system, the lowest energy configuration (the vacuum state) is not the most symmetric configuration of the system.

**Explicit Symmetry Breaking:** In theoretical physics, explicit symmetry breaking is the breaking of a symmetry of a theory by terms in its defining equations of motion (most typically, to the Lagrangian or the Hamiltonian) that do not respect the symmetry.

## Significance in Physics

This phenomenon is fundamental to quantum field theory (QFT), and further, contemporary understandings of physics. Specifically, it plays a central role in the Glashow–Weinberg–Salam model which forms part of the Standard Model modelling the electroweak sector.

## Real-World Examples

Phases of matter, such as crystals, magnets, and conventional superconductors, as well as simple phase transitions can be described by spontaneous symmetry breaking. Additionally, symmetry breaking in biology is the process by which uniformity is broken, or the number of points to view invariance are reduced, to generate a more structured and improbable state.

Web search results for query: "Ising model"

Links: [{"title":"Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_model"},{"title":"Square lattice Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Square_lattice_Ising_model"},{"title":"Transverse-field Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transverse-field_Ising_model"},{"title":"High-dimensional Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-dimensional_Ising_model"},{"title":"Two-dimensional critical Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-dimensional_critical_Ising_model"},{"title":"Ising critical exponents","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_critical_exponents"},{"title":"Ernst Ising - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Ising"},{"title":"Construction of an irreducible Markov chain in the Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Construction_of_an_irreducible_Markov_chain_in_the_Ising_model"},{"title":"Spherical model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spherical_model"},{"title":"Swendsen–Wang algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swendsen%E2%80%93Wang_algorithm"}]

Here's comprehensive information about the Ising model based on the search results:

## Overview

The Ising model, named after the physicists Ernst Ising and Wilhelm Lenz, is a mathematical model of ferromagnetism in statistical mechanics.(no content)The model consists of discrete variables that represent magnetic dipole moments of atomic "spins" that can be in one of two states (+1 or −1).

## Structure

The spins are arranged in a graph, usually a lattice (where the local structure repeats periodically in all directions), allowing each spin to interact with its neighbors.(no content)Neighboring spins that agree have a lower energy than those that disagree; the system tends to the lowest energy but heat disturbs this tendency, thus creating the possibility of different structural phases.

## Historical Development

The Ising model was invented by the physicist Wilhelm Lenz (1920), who gave it as a problem to his student Ernst Ising.(no content)The one-dimensional Ising model was solved by Ising (1925) alone in his 1924 thesis; it has no phase transition.(no content)The two-dimensional square-lattice Ising model is much harder and was only given an analytic description much later, by Lars Onsager (1944).

## Physical Significance

The two-dimensional square-lattice Ising model is one of the simplest statistical models to show a phase transition.(no content)Though it is a highly simplified model of a magnetic material, the Ising model can still provide qualitative and sometimes quantitative results applicable to real physical systems.

## Modern Applications

Today, each year, about 800 papers are published that use the model to address problems in such diverse fields as neural networks, protein folding, biological membranes and social behavior.

Links: [{"title":"Spin glass - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_glass"},{"title":"Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_model"},{"title":"Ferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferromagnetic_material"},{"title":"Antiferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antiferromagnet"},{"title":"Spin ice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_ice"},{"title":"Paramagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramagnetic"},{"title":"File:Paramagnetism, ferromagnetism and spin waves.webm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Paramagnetism,_ferromagnetism_and_spin_waves.webm"},{"title":"Talk:Paramagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Paramagnetism"},{"title":"Ferrimagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferrimagnetic_interaction"},{"title":"Magnetic structure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetic_structure"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of spin glass ferromagnetism:

## Spin Glass vs. Ferromagnetism

In ferromagnetic solids, magnetic spins all align in the same direction; this is analogous to a crystal's lattice-based structure. In contrast, a spin glass is defined as a "disordered" magnetic state in which spins are aligned randomly or without a regular pattern and the couplings too are random.

## Structure and Properties

The individual atomic bonds in a spin glass are a mixture of roughly equal numbers of ferromagnetic bonds (where neighbors have the same orientation) and antiferromagnetic bonds (where neighbors have exactly the opposite orientation).(no content)These patterns of aligned and misaligned atomic magnets create what are known as frustrated interactions – distortions in the geometry of atomic bonds compared to what would be seen in a regular, fully aligned solid.

## Key Differences from Ferromagnets

Spin glasses differ from ferromagnetic materials by the fact that after the external magnetic field is removed from a ferromagnetic substance, the magnetization remains indefinitely at the remanent value. Additionally, it is the time dependence which distinguishes spin glasses from other magnetic systems. Above the spin glass transition temperature, the spin glass exhibits typical magnetic behaviour such as paramagnetism. Upon reaching the critical temperature, the sample becomes a spin glass, and further cooling results in little change in magnetization.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Goldstone boson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldstone_boson"},{"title":"Talk:Goldstone boson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Goldstone_boson"},{"title":"Goldstone - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldstone"},{"title":"Chiral symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudo-Goldstone_boson"},{"title":"Goldstino - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldstino"},{"title":"Higgs mechanism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Higgs_mechanism"},{"title":"Composite Higgs models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Composite_Higgs_models"},{"title":"Jeffrey Goldstone - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Goldstone"},{"title":"Weakly interacting Bose gas - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weakly_interacting_Bose_gas"},{"title":"Technicolor (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technicolor_(physics)"}]

Based on the search results, here's what you need to know about Goldstone bosons:

## Definition and Discovery

Goldstone bosons or Nambu–Goldstone bosons (NGBs) are bosons that appear necessarily in models exhibiting spontaneous breakdown of continuous symmetries.(no content)They were discovered by Yoichiro Nambu within the context of the BCS superconductivity mechanism, and subsequently elucidated by Jeffrey Goldstone, and systematically generalized in the context of quantum field theory.

## Key Properties

These bosons can be thought of as the excitations of the field in the broken symmetry directions in group space—and are massless if the spontaneously broken symmetry is not also broken explicitly.(no content)If the symmetry is not exact, i.e. if it is explicitly broken as well as spontaneously broken, then the bosons that emerge are not massless, though they typically remain relatively light; they are called pseudo-Goldstone bosons or pseudo–Nambu–Goldstone bosons.

## Goldstone's Theorem

Goldstone's theorem examines a generic continuous symmetry which is spontaneously broken; i.e., its currents are conserved, but the ground state is not invariant under the action of the corresponding charges. Then, necessarily, new massless (or light, if the symmetry is not exact) scalar particles appear in the spectrum of possible excitations. There is one scalar particle—called a Nambu–Goldstone boson—for each generator of the symmetry that is broken.

## Real-World Examples

In fluids, the phonon is longitudinal and it is the Goldstone boson of the spontaneously broken Galilean symmetry.(no content)In magnets, the Goldstone bosons are the magnons, i.e., spin waves in which the local magnetization direction oscillates.

Web search results for query: "Rydberg atom"

Links: [{"title":"Rydberg atom - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rydberg_atom"},{"title":"Rydberg state - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rydberg_state"},{"title":"Rydberg constant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rydberg_constant"},{"title":"Rydberg molecule - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rydberg_molecule"},{"title":"Johannes Rydberg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johannes_Rydberg"},{"title":"Rydberg polaron - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rydberg_polaron"},{"title":"Heavy Rydberg system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heavy_Rydberg_system"},{"title":"Neutral atom quantum computer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neutral_atom_quantum_computer"},{"title":"Rydberg matter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rydberg_matter"},{"title":"Rydberg formula - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rydberg_formula"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about Rydberg atoms:

## Definition and Basic Properties

A Rydberg atom is an excited atom with one or more electrons that have a very high principal quantum number, n. The higher the value of n, the farther the electron is from the nucleus, on average.

## Characteristics

The radius of the orbit scales as n² (the n = 137 state of hydrogen has an atomic radius ~1 μm) and the geometric cross-section as n⁴. Thus, Rydberg atoms are extremely large, with loosely bound valence electrons, easily perturbed or ionized by collisions or external fields.(no content)Because the binding energy of a Rydberg electron is proportional to 1/r and hence falls off like 1/n², the energy level spacing falls off like 1/n³ leading to ever more closely spaced levels converging on the first ionization energy. These closely spaced Rydberg states form what is commonly referred to as the Rydberg series.

## Historical Background

The existence of the Rydberg series was first demonstrated in 1885 when Johann Balmer discovered a simple empirical formula for the wavelengths of light associated with transitions in atomic hydrogen. Three years later, the Swedish physicist Johannes Rydberg presented a generalized and more intuitive version of Balmer's formula that came to be known as the Rydberg formula.

## Applications

A neutral atom quantum computer is a type of quantum computers built out of Rydberg atoms; this type has many commonalities with trapped-ion quantum computers. Additionally, Rydberg matter is an exotic phase of matter formed by Rydberg atoms; it was predicted around 1980 by É. A. Manykin, M. I. Ozhovan and P. P. Poluéktov. It has been formed from various elements like caesium, potassium, hydrogen and nitrogen.

Links: [{"title":"Quantum simulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_simulator"},{"title":"Cirq - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cirq"},{"title":"Hamiltonian simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_simulation"},{"title":"IBM Quantum Platform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_Quantum_Platform"},{"title":"Quantum Monte Carlo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_Monte_Carlo"},{"title":"Quantum computational chemistry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_computational_chemistry"},{"title":"QuTiP - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QuTiP"},{"title":"Sofie Lindskov Hansen - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sofie_Lindskov_Hansen"},{"title":"Quantum artificial life - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_artificial_life"},{"title":"Quantum robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_robotics"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about quantum simulators:

## What is a Quantum Simulator?

Quantum simulators permit the study of a quantum system in a programmable fashion, with simulators being special purpose devices designed to provide insight about specific physics problems.

## Why They're Needed

Conventional computers, including supercomputers, are inadequate for simulating quantum systems with as few as 30 particles because the dimension of the Hilbert space grows exponentially with particle number.(no content)Quantum simulators can solve problems which are difficult to simulate on classical computers because they directly exploit quantum properties of real particles.

## How They Work

Quantum simulators create clean realizations of specific systems of interest, which allows precise realizations of their properties, and precise control over and broad tunability of parameters of the system allows the influence of various parameters to be cleanly disentangled.

## Experimental Platforms

Quantum simulators have been realized on a number of experimental platforms, including systems of ultracold quantum gases, polar molecules, trapped ions, photonic systems, quantum dots, and superconducting circuits.

## Software Tools

There are also software-based tools for quantum simulation. For example, QuTiP is an open-source computational physics software library for simulating quantum systems, particularly open quantum systems, and allows simulation of Hamiltonians with arbitrary time-dependence in quantum optics, ion trapping, superconducting circuits and quantum nanomechanical resonators.

Links: [{"title":"Quantum simulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_simulator"},{"title":"Cirq - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cirq"},{"title":"Hamiltonian simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_simulation"},{"title":"IBM Quantum Platform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_Quantum_Platform"},{"title":"Quantum Monte Carlo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_Monte_Carlo"},{"title":"Quantum computational chemistry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_computational_chemistry"},{"title":"QuTiP - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QuTiP"},{"title":"Sofie Lindskov Hansen - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sofie_Lindskov_Hansen"},{"title":"Quantum artificial life - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_artificial_life"},{"title":"Quantum robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_robotics"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about quantum simulators:

## What is a Quantum Simulator?

Quantum simulators permit the study of a quantum system in a programmable fashion, with simulators being special purpose devices designed to provide insight about specific physics problems.

## Why They're Needed

Conventional computers, including supercomputers, are inadequate for simulating quantum systems with as few as 30 particles because the dimension of the Hilbert space grows exponentially with particle number.(no content)Quantum simulators can solve problems which are difficult to simulate on classical computers because they directly exploit quantum properties of real particles.

## How They Work

Quantum simulators create clean realizations of specific systems of interest, which allows precise realizations of their properties, and precise control over and broad tunability of parameters of the system allows the influence of various parameters to be cleanly disentangled.

## Experimental Platforms

Quantum simulators have been realized on a number of experimental platforms, including systems of ultracold quantum gases, polar molecules, trapped ions, photonic systems, quantum dots, and superconducting circuits.

## Software Tools

There are also software-based tools for quantum simulation. For example, QuTiP is an open-source computational physics software library for simulating quantum systems, particularly open quantum systems, and allows simulation of Hamiltonians with arbitrary time-dependence in quantum optics, ion trapping, superconducting circuits and quantum nanomechanical resonators.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Antiferromagnet"

Links: [{"title":"Antiferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antiferromagnetism"},{"title":"Antiferromagnet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Antiferromagnet&redirect=no"},{"title":"Exchange bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exchange_bias"},{"title":"Magnetic structure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetic_structure"},{"title":"Ferrimagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferrimagnetism"},{"title":"Talk:Antiferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Antiferromagnetism"},{"title":"Spin canting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_canting"},{"title":"Quantum spin liquid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strongly_correlated_quantum_spin_liquid"},{"title":"Amorphous magnet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amorphous_magnet"},{"title":"Bethe ansatz - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bethe_ansatz"}]

## Antiferromagnet

In materials that exhibit antiferromagnetism, the magnetic moments of atoms or molecules, usually related to the spins of electrons, align in a regular pattern with neighboring spins (on different sublattices) pointing in opposite directions.

### Key Characteristics

When no external field is applied, the antiferromagnetic structure corresponds to a vanishing total magnetization.(no content)Antiferromagnetic order may exist at sufficiently low temperatures, but vanishes at and above the Néel temperature – named after Louis Néel, who had first identified this type of magnetic ordering.

### History

The phenomenon of antiferromagnetism was first introduced by Lev Landau in 1933.(no content)Antiferromagnetic structures were first shown through neutron diffraction of transition metal oxides such as nickel, iron, and manganese oxides, with experiments performed by Clifford Shull giving the first results showing that magnetic dipoles could be oriented in an antiferromagnetic structure.

### Common Examples

Antiferromagnetic materials occur commonly among transition metal compounds, especially oxides, with examples including hematite, metals such as chromium, alloys such as iron manganese (FeMn), and oxides such as nickel oxide (NiO).

### Practical Applications

Antiferromagnets can be used to "pin" the orientation of a ferromagnetic film, which provides one of the main uses in so-called spin valves, which are the basis of magnetic sensors including modern hard disk drive read heads.

Web search results for query: "Spontaneous symmetry breaking"

Links: [{"title":"Spontaneous symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spontaneous_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Chiral symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiral_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"1964 PRL symmetry breaking papers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1964_PRL_symmetry_breaking_papers"},{"title":"Higgs mechanism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Higgs_mechanism"},{"title":"Elitzur's theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elitzur's_theorem"},{"title":"Supersymmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supersymmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Talk:Higgs mechanism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Higgs_mechanism"},{"title":"Goldstone boson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldstone_boson"},{"title":"Time crystal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_crystal"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about spontaneous symmetry breaking:

## Definition

In spontaneous symmetry breaking (SSB), the equations of motion of the system are invariant, but any vacuum state (lowest energy state) is not. In simpler terms, spontaneous symmetry breaking occurs when this relation breaks down, while the underlying physical laws remain symmetrical.

## Key Concept

This is the idea that for a physical system, the lowest energy configuration (the vacuum state) is not the most symmetric configuration of the system.

## Physical Examples

A classic illustration is the "dome and ball" analogy: Consider a symmetric upward dome with a trough circling the bottom. If a ball is put at the very peak of the dome, the system is symmetric with respect to a rotation around the center axis. But the ball may spontaneously break this symmetry by rolling down the dome into the trough, a point of lowest energy.(no content)Phases of matter, such as crystals, magnets, and conventional superconductors, as well as simple phase transitions can be described by spontaneous symmetry breaking.

## Applications in Physics

This phenomenon is fundamental to quantum field theory (QFT), and further, contemporary understandings of physics.(no content)Specifically, it plays a central role in the Glashow–Weinberg–Salam model which forms part of the Standard Model modelling the electroweak sector.

## Notable Associated Concepts

Goldstone bosons or Nambu–Goldstone bosons (NGBs) are bosons that appear necessarily in models exhibiting spontaneous breakdown of continuous symmetries.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Quantum phase transition"

Links: [{"title":"Quantum phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_phase_transition"},{"title":"Quantum phases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_phases"},{"title":"Talk:Quantum phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Quantum_phase_transition"},{"title":"Quantum Hall transitions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_Hall_transitions"},{"title":"Dicke model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dicke_model"},{"title":"Superradiant phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superradiant_phase_transition"},{"title":"Quantum critical point - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_critical_point"},{"title":"Phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_transition"},{"title":"Kibble–Zurek mechanism","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kibble–Zurek_mechanism"},{"title":"Classical XY model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_XY_model"}]

Here are the search results for "Quantum phase transition":

## Definition and Basic Concept

In physics, a quantum phase transition (QPT) is a phase transition between different quantum phases (phases of matter at zero temperature).(no content)Contrary to classical phase transitions, quantum phase transitions can only be accessed by varying a physical parameter—such as magnetic field or pressure—at absolute zero temperature.

## Key Differences from Classical Phase Transitions

The transition describes an abrupt change in the ground state of a many-body system due to its quantum fluctuations.(no content)The classical phase transitions are driven by a competition between the energy of a system and the entropy of its thermal fluctuations. A classical system does not have entropy at zero temperature and therefore no phase transition can occur.

## Quantum Critical Behavior

Quantum fluctuations dominate the system's behavior in the region where ħω > kBT, known as the quantum critical region.(no content)This quantum critical behavior manifests itself in unconventional and unexpected physical behavior like novel non Fermi liquid phases.

## Quantum Critical Points

A quantum critical point is a point in the phase diagram of a material where a continuous phase transition takes place at absolute zero.(no content)At a quantum critical point, the critical fluctuations are quantum mechanical in nature, exhibiting scale invariance in both space and in time.

## Examples

An example of a canonical quantum phase transition is the well-studied Superconductor Insulator Transition in disordered thin films which separates two quantum phases having different symmetries.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Quantum phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_phase_transition"},{"title":"Quantum phases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_phases"},{"title":"Talk:Quantum phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Quantum_phase_transition"},{"title":"Quantum Hall transitions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_Hall_transitions"},{"title":"Dicke model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dicke_model"},{"title":"Superradiant phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superradiant_phase_transition"},{"title":"Quantum critical point - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_critical_point"},{"title":"Phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_transition"},{"title":"Kibble–Zurek mechanism","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kibble–Zurek_mechanism"},{"title":"Classical XY model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_XY_model"}]

Here are the search results for "Quantum phase transition":

## Definition and Basic Concept

In physics, a quantum phase transition (QPT) is a phase transition between different quantum phases (phases of matter at zero temperature).(no content)Contrary to classical phase transitions, quantum phase transitions can only be accessed by varying a physical parameter—such as magnetic field or pressure—at absolute zero temperature.

## Key Differences from Classical Phase Transitions

The transition describes an abrupt change in the ground state of a many-body system due to its quantum fluctuations.(no content)The classical phase transitions are driven by a competition between the energy of a system and the entropy of its thermal fluctuations. A classical system does not have entropy at zero temperature and therefore no phase transition can occur.

## Quantum Critical Behavior

Quantum fluctuations dominate the system's behavior in the region where ħω > kBT, known as the quantum critical region.(no content)This quantum critical behavior manifests itself in unconventional and unexpected physical behavior like novel non Fermi liquid phases.

## Quantum Critical Points

A quantum critical point is a point in the phase diagram of a material where a continuous phase transition takes place at absolute zero.(no content)At a quantum critical point, the critical fluctuations are quantum mechanical in nature, exhibiting scale invariance in both space and in time.

## Examples

An example of a canonical quantum phase transition is the well-studied Superconductor Insulator Transition in disordered thin films which separates two quantum phases having different symmetries.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Magnetic dipole dipole interaction"

Links: [{"title":"Magnetic dipole–dipole interaction","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetic_dipole–dipole_interaction"},{"title":"Magnetic dipole - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetic_dipole"},{"title":"Magnetic dipole transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetic_dipole_transition"},{"title":"Dipole - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dipole"},{"title":"Force between magnets - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Force_between_magnets"},{"title":"Spin–orbit interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin–orbit_interaction"},{"title":"Hyperfine structure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperfine_interaction"},{"title":"Quadrupole - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadrupole"},{"title":"Ferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferromagnetism"},{"title":"V901 Orionis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V901_Orionis"}]

Here are the search results for "Magnetic dipole dipole interaction":

## Overview

Magnetic dipole–dipole interaction, also called dipolar coupling, refers to the direct interaction between two magnetic dipoles.(no content)The magnetic field of a dipole goes as the inverse cube of the distance, and the force of its magnetic field on another dipole goes as the first derivative of this field.

## Key Characteristics

The most elementary force between magnets is the magnetic dipole–dipole interaction. If all magnetic dipoles for each magnet are known then the net force on both magnets can be determined by summing all the interactions between the dipoles of the first magnet and the dipoles of the second magnet.

## Applications

The magnetic dipole-dipole interaction is important in several fields:

- **Residual Dipolar Coupling (RDC)**: The residual dipolar coupling (RDC) occurs if the molecules in solution exhibit a partial alignment leading to an incomplete averaging of spatially anisotropic magnetic interactions i.e. dipolar couplings. RDC measurement provides information on the global folding of the protein-long distance structural information.

- **Magnetic Materials**: In ferromagnetism, the magnetic interaction between neighboring atoms' magnetic dipoles is strong enough that they align with each other regardless of any applied field, resulting in the spontaneous magnetization of so-called domains.

- **Hyperfine Structure**: The dominant term in the hyperfine Hamiltonian is typically the magnetic dipole term.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Continuous symmetry breaking in a two-dimensional Rydberg array". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (proposes new experimental realization of the dipolar XY model)

**Key Findings:** The analysis extracted and validated 12 key triples from the paper:

### Core Concepts Used:
- **Spontaneous symmetry breaking** - Fundamental to phase transitions in the system
- **Symmetry breaking** - Theoretical framework for phase classification
- **Phase transition** - Describes transitions between ordered phases
- **Goldstone boson** - Gapless modes emerging from continuous symmetry
- **Ising model** - Contrasted with the XY model (discrete vs continuous symmetry)
- **Ferromagnetism** - One of the phases studied
- **Antiferromagnetism** - Complementary phase studied
- **Magnetic dipole** - Essential long-range interactions
- **Quantum phase transition** - Transitions explored through adiabatic preparation

### Novel Contributions (Proposes):
- **Classical XY model** - Realized experimentally in 2D with dipolar interactions
- **Quantum simulator** - Demonstrated using Rydberg atoms for studying many-body physics

### Tools/Artifacts Used:
- **Rydberg atom** - Forms basis of the programmable quantum simulator

All Wikipedia URLs have been validated and the JSON file has passed validation checks. The triples_output.json file is ready for use.

Sources:
- [Spontaneous symmetry breaking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spontaneous_symmetry_breaking)
- [Symmetry breaking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking)
- [Goldstone boson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldstone_boson)
- [Classical XY model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_XY_model)
- [Rydberg atom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rydberg_atom)
- [Quantum simulator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_simulator)
- [Ising model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_model)
- [Ferromagnetism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferromagnetism)
- [Antiferromagnetism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antiferromagnetism)
